docTitle.titlePart:
Diffusion Coefficients of Aromatic Hydrocarbons in Their Lowest
Triplet State : Anthracene in Hexane, Octane , Hexadecane,
Perfluorohexane, and Methylcyclohexane ; Pyrene and 9,10-Di-
phenylanthracene in Hexane

byline.docAuthor: E. Georg Meyer and Bernhard Nickel

titlePage.byline: Max-Planck-Institut für Biophysikalische Chemie, Abteilung Spektroskopie, Göttingen

front.div:
An experimental method is described which allows the determination of the diffusion coeffi-
cient D of an aromatic hydrocarbon in its lowest and metastable triplet state T\ with an absolute
accuracy of ±5%. D was determined at 25 °C. With anthracene the temperature-dependence
of D was measured from 0°C to 00°C in hexane and from 20°C to 89°C in hexadecane ; it was
found to be in good but not perfect agreement with the Stokes-Einstein equation. With the
investigated systems, D of molecules in Ti is estimated to be at most 10% smaller than D of
molecule« in the ground state. No evidence for the formation of triplet excimers was found.
Some applications of the method are proposed, and in this connection some questions concerning
the kinetics of diffusion-controlled reactions of molecules in T\ and the existence of triplet
excimers are discussed.
